references: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
Tumlison, R., and G. R. Cline. 2003. Association between the Oklahoma salamander (Eurycea tynerensis) and Ordovician-Silurian strata. Southwestern Naturalist 48:93-95.

Bury, R. B., C. K. Dodd, Jr., and G. M. Fellers. 1980. Conservation of the Amphibia of the United States:a review. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Washington, D.C., Resource Publication 134. 34 pp.
Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
Cline, G.R., and R. Tumlison. 2001. Distribution and relative abundance of the Oklahoma salamander (Eurycea tynerensis). Proceedings of the Oklahoma Academy of Science 81:1-10.
habitat_description: "The Oklahoma salamander inhabits small creeks and springs which have loose gravel. It is usually found in the loose gravel but also has been found in aquatic vegetation growing in their cold water creeks." (Wilson 1995). They prefer shallow, slow-flowing areas with medium-sized rocks of low to moderate embeddedness near stream margins where aquatic invertebrate prey are abundant (Tumlison et al. 1990, Petranka 1998). Because they require cold, clean, rocky and/or gravelly, creeks and springs, any activites that degrade water quality will have negative effects on this species (Wilson 1995). E. tynerensis is closely associated with Ordovician-Silurian strata (Tumlison and Cline 2003), and is generally found in streams at elevations below 305 meters (Bury et al. 1980).
